hints_html: The matrix U only reveals information about the homogeneous system \(Ay = 0\). Can you rewrite the given equation to a homogeneous system?
hints_latex:
The matrix \emph{U} only reveals information about the homogeneous
system $Ay = 0$. Can you rewrite the given equation to a homogeneous
system?
hints_raw: The matrix ''U'' only reveals information about the homogeneous system <math> Ay = 0 </math>. Can you rewrite the given equation to a homogeneous system?
question: B 03 (c)
sols_html:
Rewriting the given equation gives

\[\begin{aligned} A\mathbf{x} &= A\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ -2\end{bmatrix} \\ 0 &= A\mathbf{x} - A\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ -2\end{bmatrix} \\ &= A\underbrace{\left(\mathbf{x}-\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ -2\end{bmatrix}\right)}_{=\mathbf{y}}\end{aligned}\]

From part (a) we know that the solution to this homogeneous equation is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{y} = a\begin{bmatrix} 7 \\ -4 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

Solving for x we obtain

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{x} = \mathbf{y} + \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ -2\end{bmatrix} = a\begin{bmatrix} 7 \\ -4 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ -2\end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

Since U can be obtained from A by elementary row operations, there is an invertible matrix E such that A = EU. Hence

\[\begin{aligned} Ax &= A\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ -2 \end{bmatrix} \\ EUx &= EU\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ -2 \end{bmatrix} \\ Ux &= U\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ -2 \end{bmatrix} \\ \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & -7 \\ 0 & 1 & 4 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \\ x_3 \end{bmatrix} &= \begin{bmatrix} 14 \\ -7 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

We see that x3 is a free parameter. Further, x1 - 7x3 = 14 implies x1 = 7x3+14 and x2 + 4x3 = -7 implies x2 = -4x3 -7. Therefore, the solution is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 7x_3 + 14 \\ -4x_3 - 7 \\ x_3 \end{bmatrix} = x_3\begin{bmatrix} 7 \\ -4 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix} 14 \\ -7 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

where x3 is any constant.

Note that the set of solutions found here is the same as the set of solutions found in solution 1, see by setting \(\displaystyle a = x_{3} + 2\).
statement_html:
Let A be a certain \(2\times 3\) matrix. Suppose that using elementary row operations, the matrix A can be transformed into the matrix

\[\begin{aligned} U = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & -7 \\ 0 & 1 & 4 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

Find all solutions, if any, of the system \(Ax = A\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ -2 \end{bmatrix}\)
statement_raw:
Let ''A'' be a certain <math>2\times 3 </math> matrix. Suppose that using elementary row operations, the matrix ''A'' can be transformed into the matrix 

:<math>
U = \begin{bmatrix} 
1 & 0 & -7 \\
0 & 1 & 4
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

Find all solutions, if any, of the system <math> Ax = A\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ -2 \end{bmatrix}</math>
